SECOND CLASS HACKNEY CARRIAGE DRIVING LICENCES


    2. Mr Bernard Rodrigues asked the Deputy Prime Minister (a) if he will explain why there are only 3,213 Second Class Hackney Carriage Licences issued up to August 1965, as against 13,032 Hackney Carriage Driving Licences issued up to the same month; (b) whether he is aware of hardship caused to holders of Second Class Hackney Carriage Driving Licences by this imbalance, and (c) if he will undertake

Column: 265

to stop issuing further Second Class Hackney Carriage Driving Licences, and increase the number of Second Class Hackney Carriage Licences.

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj (for the Deputy Prime Minister)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, in July 1959 the issue of taxi driving licences was stopped. Four years later in 1963, representations were made by taxi owners that there was difficulty in looking for taxi drivers to man their vehicles. Petitions had also been submitted from members of the public asking for a resumption of the issue of taxi driving licences. Because of these petitions, a Committee was appointed by the Deputy Prime Minister in 1963 to ascertain the correct ratio of taxi drivers to the number of second class hackney carriages (i.e., taxis).

    In 1963, there were 3,185 motor vehicles licensed as second class hackney carriages, i.e., as taxis. If it is argued that all these vehicles were operating, and 2 drivers are required to operate one taxi during a 24-hour period, then the total number of taxi drivers would be 6,370. This simple arithmetic, however, does not fit into the actual requirements of the taxi business. Taxi drivers, like all other workers, must have their rest days in any week, and it is not always possible for a taxi driver to remain at the wheel continuously for periods as long as 12 hours at a stretch. Therefore, the total number of persons that would be required to operate the 3,185 taxis is actually higher than the figure of 6,370, and a ratio of 3 drivers to one taxi would probably be more correct, giving allowances for sick leave, resignations, etc. This should bring the figure of persons holding taxi driving licences to 9,555. In actual fact, at the end of 1963 there were 9,841 persons holding taxi drivers' licences. However, the Committee found that not all these licence holders were engaged in driving taxis as a full-time occupation.

    It was ascertained that a great number of these licence holders either were not engaged in driving taxis at all, or were only engaged in driving taxis as

Column: 266

a part-time occupation. Some of these licence holders, according to the evidence submitted to the Committee, are shop assistants, hawkers, lorry drivers or attendants, bus drivers or conductors, subordinate staff in commercial firms, and even Government servants. They drive taxis whenever they can during public holidays or during their off-duty hours to earn some extra income. There are other licence holders who, although they are at the moment not engaged in driving taxis at all, renew their licences year after year with a view to making use of them in case they lose their present jobs. Yet a number of the licence holders are garage owners or motor mechanics who require these licences to drive taxis for the purpose of testing the vehicles.

    For these various reasons, it was decided to resume the issue of taxi driving licences but only to those who were unemployed and had registered at the Labour Exchange. At present, l3,414 taxi driving licences have been issued, but this figure is small in comparison with the total number of ordinary driing licences which is 368,408.

    The problem does not lie in the number of holders of taxi driving licences but in the number of taxis permitted to ply on the roads. At present, there are 3,193 taxis. The Government had in the Past indicated that the number of taxis plying on the roads must have relationship to public demand and that the number would be reviewed from time to time. It is my intention now to review the position of public transport and I shall set up a Committee to investigate and make recommendations.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister indicate when he intends to set up this Committee and if he will include the Singapore Taxi Drivers' Association on it?

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj(In Malay): This matter will be considered and even if they are not selected, the Committee will still receive opinions which they hope may be constructive in nature.

COMMUNITY CENTRES AT JALAN PENGGAGA AND GEYLANG SERAI


    3. Inche Rahamat Bin Kenap asked the Minister of Defence (a) whether Government has any plans to improve the community centre at Jalan Penggaga and to construct additional ones in the Geylang Serai Constituency; and (b) when will such plans be implemented.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the community centre at Jalan Penggaga is housed in a building which is rented from one person who is not in Singapore, and the land belongs to another party. Therefore, it is not advisable to spend money on structural improvement in these circumstances. Improvement of all community centres in other respects is continually attempted by way of recruitment of better qualified staff, training of staff and appointment of management committees. The Assemblyman of the area is usually invited to be the adviser of the management committee and it is his responsibility, as much as that of the Government, to improve the amenities and activities of community centres.

    In reply to the second part of the question, the Government plans to build another standard type community centre at Geylang Serai. In fact, it has already acquired a site. But we do not have enough money for the construction of this centre until sometime after 1966.

    Inche Rahamat Bin Kenap (Geylang Serai)(In Malay): 1 wish to inquire of the Minister, since the P.A.P. came to power, the Government has been building community centres throughout Singapore. This is a matter of pride. But it is a pity that after the P.A.P. came to power, there has been no project for Geylang Serai -

    Mr Speaker: If the Member has a supplementary question to ask, he may do so. But he must not embark on a speech. A supplementary, please.

    Inche Rahamat(In Malay): This is related to my question. May I inquire why the Geylang Serai constituency does not have a community centre as

Column: 268

other constituencies have? Is there something wrong why there is no community centre in Geylang Serai?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, there is one community centre. As I said, this is in a rather ancient building of wooden structure. The owner of the building is now staying, I am told, in Indonesia. The landlord is somewhere else. Obviously it is a risky thing to effect improvements to this particular place. Geylang Serai, of course, is fortunate in having at least one community centre. There are three other constituencies which have none whatsoever, and the Member is therefore comparatively fortunate. After 1966, as I said, we can look forward to having another one. He must, in the meantime, contain his soul in patience.

COMMUNITY CENTRE AT JALAN SEMBAWANG KECHIL

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask a supplementary question. According to what I know, there is a regulation stipulated by the Government that if there are 200 families they are entitled to one community centre. I would like to ask the Minister whether he is going to implement this policy according to the regulation.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I am not aware of such a regulation. I think what the hon. Member is referring to was a statement of intention made sometime I think after the referendum - 1962 is

Column: 269

it? - when the Government made a statement saying that if there are more than 200 families living in a village, we will try to build a rural type community centre. Preference, of course, will be given to the Barisan areas where their influence is strong, so that the population may be instructed in the correct way in order that falsehood may be confronted with truth. For this reason, during 1962 and 1963, there was quite an active programme of building rural community centres, and we laid down as the minimum criterion that unless there are at least 200 families, then we would not consider building a community centre. This does not mean, of course, that there must be a community centre for every 200 families. If, in fact, we take this literally, then we will have in Singapore something like 200,000 community centres.

THIRD CLASS PATIENTS IN
KANDANG KERBAU
(Inadequate hospital clothing)


    10. Mrs Devan Nair asked the Minister for Health if he is aware that third class patients in the Kandang Kerbau Maternity Hospital are provided with hospital clothing that is so inadequate as to improperly expose portions of their bodies, and if he will give instructions that this state of affairs he remedied as soon as possible.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, I have been asked by the Minister to answer. It is not true that patients in Kandang Kerbau Maternity Hospital are being provided with hospital clothing which is inadequate. The clothing provided for female `C' Class patients in this Maternity Hospital are standard type, that is, white bajus and red sarongs, similar to those for other Government hospitals. It is possible, however, that some patients who are not accustomed to wearing sarongs may inadvertently expose themselves on change of posture.

    Ambulant patients (i.e., those who can walk on their own) whilst on their way to and from operating theatres or labour wards are provided with kimono-type gowns. Patients on stretchers are clothed in maternity gowns and always covered over by a blanket.

    The only time where patients may expose themselves is in the labour ward, i.e., when patients are already in labour. However, in this section, only doctors, nurses or midwives are present. Visitors are not allowed inside the Labour Ward.

    Mrs Devan Nair (Moulmein)(In Tamil): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask a supplementary question. The Parliamentary Secretary has said that kimonos are given to those in the wards after surgery. Does he know that some

Column: 273

parts of the kimonos have no buttons - open at the back? Some do not have elastic bands. Does it not appear to the Minister that the patients have to hold on to the dress with their hands where-ever there are no buttons? Male attendants laugh at the patients. Is the Minister not aware of this? Will he do something to remedy the situation?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I think the patients are in a position to look after themselves at that stage. They are not entirely helpless. If the kimono has not got any buttons - I do not know; there may well be cases where the buttons come off in the laundry and they have not been replaced. But I should imagine they will be replaced as soon as they are discovered missing. If the patients will take a little bit of care, I do not think this sort of thing will happen.

HOLLAND ROAD MARKET


    11. Mr Chow Chiok Hock asked the Minister for Health whether and when a new market will be constructed at the 5th mile area in Holland Road; or alternatively the present market be renovated to serve the needs of the hawkers and residents in the area.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, the present market at Holland Road of 43 stalls is considered adequate for the needs of the hawkers and residents in this vicinity at the present time. As a result of recent re-siting of 76 hawkers outside the market, some market stalls have been taken up. However, there are still 4 market stalls and 18 open pitches which are vacant. There is, therefore, no immediate need to build a new market. The question of renovation and improvements to the present Holland Road Market could be looked into when the need arises. There is no scheme for a new market to be built at Holland Road in the Government's Second Five-Year Development Plan.

STRIKE AT HUP SENG BEE-HOON FACTORY
(Request for Statement)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Poh Ber Liak :-

    13. To ask the Minister for Labour if he will make a statement on the strike of workers at Hup Seng Bee-Hoon Factory at Changi Road, 10 m.s., in July, 1965.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan) rose ---

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): A supplementary question, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Ho, you are somewhat late. I have called the Question. Inche Mohd. Ariff.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi(In Malay): As Mr Poh Ber Liak is absent, I would like to put the question to the Minister for Labour.

    The Minister for Labour (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am grateful to the Member for Kampong Kembangan for giving me this opportunity to expose one of the wrong doings of the Communist unions in the labour field. It is rather surprising that the Member for Tampines should have originally tabled this question regarding the so-called strike at the Hup Seng Bee-Hoon Factory, for in this particular case it is he and his Communist friends, or rather the union which is under their

Column: 275

control, that should make a statement to the public as to why they should not be condemned for causing the unemployment of 18 workers and the closing down of the factory. These workers worked in the factory premises of Hup Seng and Company in the manufacture of bee-hoon. Amongst them they had their own head, a man named Low Ah Seng. They worked on a tonnage basis of $6 per picul. The system appeared to be that all the workmen collectively participated in manufacturing the bee-hoon and then shared the earnings equally among themselves. The factory premises and the equipment belonged to Hup Seng and Company, and the rice for the manufacture of bee-boon was supplied by the Company. The workmen made the bee-hoon in their own time. They were not under the direct supervision of the Company. In fact, they were what is normally termed "independent contractors". There was no written agreement between the Company and the workers. The Company had never paid Central Provident Fund contributions in respect of any of them. The C.P.F. Board had investigated into this matter in August 1964 and was satisfied that the Company was not an employer. These arrangements had been going on for some ten years until September 1964, when a Communist-dominated union, the Singapore Commercial Houses and Factory Employees' Union, came into the picture. It created a dispute out of a case where the Company was reported to have told one worker to stop work. There were two unfruitful meetings in my Ministry. The Company refused to negotiate with the Union on the ground that the Company was not the employer. This led to a strike in October 1964. The Union, on the advice of their learned lawyer, Mr T. T. Rajah, tried to force the case in the Labour Court. But the Labour Court decided that no employer-employee relationship existed between the Company and the workers. This decision was later upheld by the High Court.

    Meanwhile the Company was strike-bound for months. It finally had to close down in February 1965.

Column: 276



    The case was simple. Since there was no employer-employee relationship between the Company and the workers, there could not be any industrial dispute. The system of production prevailing in this Company has been existing in Singapore for years, especially among the smaller factories. Because of the unnecessary militancy and the stupidity of the Communist-dominated Singapore Commercial Houses and Factory Employees' Union, 18 workers lost the opportunity to earn their living.
